title: Video shows corrections officers brawling in elevator at Boston jail
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: Three corrections officers were involved in a fight in an elevator at Suffolk County House of Correction Saturday morning.
The incident, captured on video, started when a cup of coffee was knocked out of an officer's hand.
The Suffolk County Sheriff’s Department is investigating and plans to take appropriate disciplinary action.

title: Asparagus could soon become Massachusetts’ official state vegetable
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Massachusetts may designate asparagus as its official state vegetable through a bill filed by Rep. Homar Gomez and Sen. Jo Comerford.
Asparagus, historically significant in Hadley, Massachusetts, was once dubbed the 'asparagus capital of the world'.
The bill promoting asparagus recognition follows a push from Hadley Elementary School students and is currently under committee review.

title: Paula Cole wants to spend Valentine’s Day with you
author: Lauren Daley
bullets: Paula Cole will perform a Valentine's Day concert at Groton Hill Music Center in Groton.
Cole plans to release a 64-track archival collection, 'Sonic Memoir', alongside her 'This Fire: 30' tour.
The 'This Fire: 30' tour begins in September, celebrating the album's 30th anniversary, including a Boston show.

title: Boston meteorologists say Monday’s storm is ‘trending toward a miss’
author: John Waller
bullets: Meteorologists report that Monday's storm is likely to track too far offshore to affect Boston significantly.
Some flurries and snow showers are expected near the coast, but a mostly calm weather pattern is anticipated.
A milder weather pattern is expected next week with temperatures reaching the 40s in Boston.

title: 5 best new restaurant openings and dining updates in Boston (Feb. 12, 2026)
author: Katelyn Umholtz
bullets: Citrus & Salt is opening a second location in Burlington this summer with colorful decor and an expansive patio.
Moro Mou, a 15-seat omakase blending Greek and Japanese cuisines, is set to open in Seaport in summer 2026.
The Down Low, a cocktail-focused supper club with live entertainment, opened in January 2026 in Woburn.

title: Nikola Vucevic, Celtics roll into All-Star break with blowout win over Bulls: 7 takeaways
author: Tom Westerholm
bullets: Nikola Vucevic scored 19 points with 11 rebounds in Celtics' 124-105 win over Bulls in his third game with Boston.
Payton Pritchard contributed 26 points as the Celtics prepared for the All-Star break with a decisive victory.
The Celtics head into the All-Star break leading the Knicks by one game, with Jayson Tatum's return anticipated post-break.

title: ‘Modern day concentration camp’: Irish man living in Boston area has been in ICE detention for 5 months
author: Molly Farrar
bullets: Seamus Culleton, an Irish man in Boston, has been in ICE detention for five months after overstaying his visa.
Culleton's detention, described as inhumane, occurred after ICE agents checked his license plate at a Home Depot in Saugus.
Legal disputes arise as DHS claims Culleton was offered removal to Ireland; his lawyer argues for release based on marriage to a U.S. citizen.

title: Will Patriots move on from Stefon Diggs? Maye says WR has a lot ‘left in the tank’
author: Conor Ryan
bullets: Stefon Diggs could be a cap casualty for New England Patriots despite his strong 2025 season performance.
Releasing Diggs before June 1 could save the Patriots $16.8 million, or $20.8 million if post-June 1.
Diggs faces legal issues, including charges of assault and strangulation, which may affect his future with the team.

title: Watch: Maynard police, fire crews save dog from ‘pet owner’s worst nightmare’
author: Darin Zullo
bullets: Maynard police and fire crews rescued a dog from Mill Pond after it fell through the ice.
The rescue took place at 9 p.m. using a drone to guide firefighters, saving the dog in under 10 minutes.
The dog, named Rufus, was returned home safely without serious injuries, confirmed by Maynard Fire Chief Angela Lawless.

title: Signal issues cause multiple delays and cancellations on at least 6 commuter rail lines
author: Carson Lyle
bullets: Signal issues caused delays and cancellations on all 12 MBTA commuter rail lines starting Wednesday morning.
More than 25 trains were canceled with delays reaching up to 50 minutes, according to the MBTA.
Blue Line had a power problem causing a temporary shutdown between Orient Heights and Wonderland, now resolved.
